headers.title: Introduction
headers.content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a transformative force across industries, offering innovative solutions to complex problems through data-driven approaches. This assignment focuses on exploring the uses and applications of AI within a business context, specifically through the development of a predictive model aimed at addressing student academic outcomes. By leveraging a real-world dataset from a higher education institution, which includes academic, demographic, and socio-economic factors known at enrollment, this project investigates how AI techniques such as logistic regression and linear regression can be applied to classify student statuses and predict academic performance. The objective is to provide actionable insights that can help reduce dropout rates and improve student success, demonstrating the practical benefits, challenges, and ethical considerations involved in AI deployment. The work also encompasses the full AI development pipeline from data preparation and model training to evaluation and refinement, using Python and Google Colab as the computational tools.

headers.title: A.P1. Describe how the fundamental concepts of AI are used in industry to meet specific identified needs
headers.content:
Fundamental Concepts of AI
 Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems. The fundamental concepts of AI include:

  • Machine Learning (ML) – systems that learn from data and improve without being explicitly programmed.

  • Natural Language Processing (NLP) – understanding and generating human language.

  • Computer Vision – interpreting and processing visual data like images or videos.

  • Robotics and Automation – using AI to automate physical tasks.

  • Knowledge Representation and Reasoning – how AI stores and processes knowledge to make decisions.

Use of AI in Industry

1. Healthcare
 AI is transforming healthcare by improving diagnostics, treatment, and patient care. Machine learning models are trained on medical data (X-rays, patient records, etc.) to detect diseases like cancer at early stages. For example, DeepMind developed an AI that can diagnose over 50 eye conditions as accurately as human doctors. NLP is also used in chatbots for mental health support and virtual assistants for scheduling and monitoring medication.

2. Finance
 In the financial industry, AI is used for fraud detection, algorithmic trading, credit scoring, and customer support. Machine learning models can identify unusual patterns in transactions to detect fraud in real-time. AI also powers robo-advisors that automatically manage investment portfolios for users. These tools help banks and fintech companies reduce risk, improve customer experience, and make faster decisions.

3. Education
 AI in education is applied through personalized learning platforms, automated grading systems, and early dropout prediction—which is closely related to my project. Universities and schools use predictive models to identify students at risk of failure or dropping out, allowing early intervention. For example, platforms like Knewton or Squirrel AI adapt the curriculum based on each student’s performance, helping improve learning outcomes.

4. Retail and E-Commerce
 AI is widely used to improve the shopping experience. It powers product recommendations, customer service chatbots, inventory management, and price optimization. Amazon, for example, uses AI to recommend products based on user behavior and past purchases. Computer vision is used in smart stores to track products without barcode scanning (e.g., Amazon Go).

5. Transportation
 AI helps improve traffic management, route optimization, and autonomous driving. Companies like Tesla use deep learning to build self-driving features, allowing cars to detect obstacles, signs, and other vehicles. Logistics companies use AI to optimize delivery routes and predict shipping delays based on weather and traffic data.

6. Manufacturing
 In manufacturing, AI is used for predictive maintenance, quality control, and process optimization. Sensors collect data from machines, and AI models predict when a machine is likely to fail, reducing downtime. Computer vision is also used to inspect products for defects during production.

Conclusion
 The core ideas of AI—like learning from data, recognizing patterns, and making intelligent decisions—are now essential tools across many industries. Whether it's diagnosing diseases, detecting fraud, personalizing education, or automating factories, AI is helping meet specific business and societal needs more efficiently and effectively. As AI continues to evolve, its impact on industries will only grow deeper and more integrated.

headers.title: A.P2. Explain the associated benefits, risks and drawbacks of AI in different industries
headers.content:
Introduction
 AI is now widely used across many industries, and it brings both benefits and risks. While AI can improve efficiency, accuracy, and save costs, it also raises concerns like bias, privacy, job loss, and system failures. Below I will explain the key benefits and drawbacks of AI, using real industry examples.

Healthcare

Benefits

  • Early diagnosis: AI can detect diseases like cancer earlier than humans, using deep learning on X-rays or scans.

  • Faster decisions: Doctors get help from AI tools to make quicker treatment plans.

  • Operational efficiency: Chatbots can handle patient queries, reducing pressure on hospital staff.

Risks and Drawbacks

  • Bias in data: If the AI is trained on biased or incomplete data, it may give wrong diagnoses—especially on underrepresented groups.

  • Privacy: Patient records are sensitive, and if AI systems are not secured properly, personal health data could be leaked or misused.

  • Lack of transparency: AI models are often "black boxes"—doctors may not understand how a diagnosis was made.

Finance

Benefits

  • Fraud detection: AI can analyze thousands of transactions per second and detect fraud in real-time.

  • Algorithmic trading: AI reacts faster than humans to changes in stock markets.

  • Better customer service: AI-powered chatbots give 24/7 banking support.

Risks and Drawbacks

  • Automation of jobs: AI reduces the need for human workers in customer service and data analysis.

  • False positives: Fraud detection systems may wrongly block transactions.

  • Data security: Financial AI systems are prime targets for hacking.

Education

Benefits

  • Personalized learning: AI adapts content based on student performance, helping weaker students improve faster.

  • Dropout prediction: AI can identify at-risk students early, like in the dataset I used.

  • Efficient marking: AI can automate grading for multiple-choice or short-answer questions.

Risks and Drawbacks

  • Loss of human interaction: Overreliance on AI may reduce student-teacher engagement.

  • Bias: If AI uses biased data (e.g., students from one region performing worse), it may wrongly judge student performance.

  • Privacy: Student data collected by AI platforms must be handled responsibly.

Retail and E-commerce

Benefits

  • Product recommendations: AI boosts sales by showing users what they’re most likely to buy.

  • Stock management: AI predicts which items to restock, avoiding over- or under-supply.

  • Customer service: AI chatbots respond instantly, improving the shopping experience.

Risks and Drawbacks

  • Job loss: Self-checkout systems and automated warehouses reduce the need for workers.

  • Bias in recommendations: Some items or sellers may be favored unfairly by algorithms.

  • Privacy: AI tracks user behavior, which raises concerns about how much data is being collected.

Manufacturing

Benefits

  • Predictive maintenance: AI predicts when a machine will break, reducing downtime and saving money.

  • Quality control: AI spots defects faster than humans using image recognition.

  • Automation: Robots powered by AI speed up production.

Risks and Drawbacks

  • Dependence on AI: If the system fails, the whole process can stop.

  • Skill gaps: Workers need new skills to work with AI, and not everyone gets trained.

  • Initial cost: Setting up AI systems in factories is expensive.

Conclusion
 AI is a powerful technology that’s transforming industries, but it’s not perfect. While it increases productivity and can solve complex problems faster than humans, it also introduces new risks that must be carefully managed—especially around privacy, bias, and job loss. A balanced approach is needed where AI supports humans, but does not replace critical judgment or reduce fairness.

headers.title: A.M1. Analyse the benefits, risks and drawbacks of AI and how they impact on different industries
headers.content:
Introduction
 AI is being integrated into many industries today, and its influence is growing quickly. It brings important benefits like increased efficiency, automation, better predictions, and improved decision-making. But at the same time, it introduces risks like bias, data privacy issues, and over-dependence. In this task, I will analyse these benefits and drawbacks and explain how they impact industries differently, depending on how AI is used.


Healthcare Industry

Positive Impacts of AI
 AI is helping doctors to detect diseases earlier and more accurately. For example, deep learning can find signs of cancer in X-rays or scans that might be missed by humans. This leads to better outcomes for patients and faster diagnosis. AI chatbots and virtual assistants reduce the workload of medical staff by handling routine questions.

Negative Impacts and Risks
 However, the risk is that biased or incomplete training data may lead to inaccurate diagnoses, especially for minorities who are underrepresented in the training data. There is also a lack of transparency, as many AI models are black boxes. Another serious concern is data privacy, since health data is extremely sensitive. Any breach can have serious consequences for patients.

Industry Impact
 While AI increases the capacity of healthcare systems and helps reach more patients, it also forces hospitals to invest in better cybersecurity and ensure transparency in AI systems, which requires both time and money.


Finance Industry

Positive Impacts of AI
 In finance, AI improves fraud detection by monitoring thousands of transactions and spotting patterns humans can’t. It also improves algorithmic trading, helping firms make better investment decisions in real-time. AI chatbots in banking reduce waiting times and improve customer experience.

Negative Impacts and Risks
 But the risks are high. For example, false positives in fraud detection can block genuine transactions. Job losses are a major concern as customer service and data analysis roles are automated. Also, financial AI systems are a target for cyber-attacks.

Industry Impact
 Banks and financial companies gain a competitive edge through AI, but they also have to spend heavily on cybersecurity and retrain staff, because many jobs are changing or disappearing.


Education Industry

Positive Impacts of AI
 AI helps students through personalized learning systems that adapt to each student’s pace. It can predict student dropouts, just like in the project I worked on using the "Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success" dataset. This helps schools act early and support students who are struggling.

Negative Impacts and Risks
 But using AI too much may reduce human interaction, which is important in learning. There is also a risk of bias, if the training data does not fairly represent all student types. Student data privacy must also be managed carefully.

Industry Impact
 Education becomes more data-driven and efficient, but schools must monitor AI tools carefully to avoid unfair decisions or privacy breaches. Teachers also need training to work alongside AI effectively.


Retail Industry

Positive Impacts of AI
 Retailers use AI for recommendation systems, predicting what customers want to buy. AI also improves inventory control, reducing waste. Customer service chatbots give 24/7 support.

Negative Impacts and Risks
 The biggest risk is loss of jobs, like cashiers being replaced by self-checkout systems. Also, recommendation systems can create bias, promoting certain products or sellers unfairly. AI also collects lots of user data, raising privacy concerns.

Industry Impact
 AI boosts profits and customer satisfaction but retailers must balance automation with human jobs and take care not to misuse user data.


Manufacturing Industry

Positive Impacts of AI
 AI improves quality control using computer vision, spots defects, and supports predictive maintenance, reducing machine downtime. It makes factories more productive and less wasteful.

Negative Impacts and Risks
 Factories become highly dependent on AI and robotic systems, which can be a problem if systems break or data is incorrect. There is also a lack of skilled workers who can manage and maintain AI systems. Training workers takes time and investment.

Industry Impact
 Production becomes faster and more consistent, but the initial costs are high, and jobs for low-skilled workers decrease. Companies must plan how to upskill their workforce.


Conclusion
 AI clearly brings huge benefits like efficiency, speed, and better decision-making, but it also creates new challenges in every industry. The impact of AI depends on how responsibly it is implemented. Industries that prepare well by training staff, protecting data, and monitoring AI decisions will benefit the most, while those that ignore the risks may face serious problems like bias, inequality, or security breaches. In every case, AI should support human workers, not fully replace them.

headers.title: A.D1. Evaluate the impact of AI on different industries
headers.content:
Introduction
 Artificial Intelligence (AI) has had a massive impact across many industries, changing how work is done, decisions are made, and how businesses interact with customers. In this task, I will evaluate the impact of AI on five key industries: healthcare, finance, education, retail, and manufacturing. I will focus on both the positive transformations and the challenges that AI introduces.

Healthcare Industry

Transformations through AI
 AI has made a big difference in diagnosis, treatment planning, and medical research. AI-powered tools are able to analyze medical images faster and more accurately than some doctors. It helps detect diseases like cancer earlier, leading to better patient outcomes. AI also supports virtual assistants and chatbots that answer patient questions, saving doctors' time.

Long-Term Impact
 The healthcare sector is becoming more efficient and more predictive. However, the long-term risk is reliance on systems that may contain bias or errors. If AI misdiagnoses a condition because of biased data, this can put lives at risk. Additionally, there's a concern about data privacy, since patient data is very sensitive.

Overall Evaluation
 AI has positively transformed healthcare by improving speed and accuracy, but hospitals must manage ethical concerns, data safety, and human oversight to avoid mistakes.


Finance Industry

Transformations through AI
 AI is used for fraud detection, risk assessment, and automated trading. It helps banks identify suspicious transactions in real-time and offers personalized financial services to customers. AI chatbots reduce customer service costs and speed up response times.

Long-Term Impact
 AI gives finance companies a huge competitive advantage, but it also introduces new challenges. For example, algorithms can wrongly flag legitimate transactions as fraud. Automation can also lead to job loss, especially in customer-facing or repetitive roles. Finally, cybersecurity threats increase when systems are online and constantly processing sensitive data.

Overall Evaluation
 AI is changing how financial services operate, making them faster and more efficient, but the need for transparency and security has also increased a lot.


Education Industry

Transformations through AI
 In education, AI helps personalise learning through adaptive platforms. It also helps schools predict student outcomes—something I explored myself using the Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success dataset. Using AI, I was able to see how certain features predicted whether a student was at risk of dropping out, which can help schools take early action.

Long-Term Impact
 AI can make education more inclusive and personalised, but also risks reducing human interaction. Students may become over-reliant on machines, and bias in the data can result in unfair treatment of some students. Also, AI systems require careful monitoring and transparent decision-making.

Overall Evaluation
 AI has the potential to revolutionise education, especially in terms of identifying and helping at-risk students, but it should be used to support teachers, not replace them.


Retail Industry

Transformations through AI
 Retailers use AI for product recommendations, customer behavior analysis, and inventory management. AI can suggest products to customers based on their preferences and past actions. It also helps reduce waste by managing stock levels more accurately.

Long-Term Impact
 The customer experience is becoming more personalised and efficient. However, jobs like cashiers and customer service reps are being replaced by automation. Also, the amount of data collected about users is growing fast, creating serious privacy risks.

Overall Evaluation
 AI has made retail smarter and faster, but privacy and ethical marketing practices must be considered. There is also a social impact from job automation that must be addressed by retraining and education.


Manufacturing Industry

Transformations through AI
 In manufacturing, AI is used for quality inspection, predictive maintenance, and even robotic automation of the production process. Machines can now detect defects and predict breakdowns before they happen.

Long-Term Impact
 AI leads to higher productivity, less waste, and better safety, but at the same time, it reduces the need for low-skilled workers. There is also a skills gap, as workers now need to understand how to work with advanced AI and robotics systems.

Overall Evaluation
 Manufacturing becomes faster, safer, and more efficient thanks to AI, but this requires investment in workforce training and infrastructure to ensure long-term sustainability.


Conclusion

AI has made a significant and mostly positive impact on multiple industries. From helping doctors diagnose faster to supporting students at risk of failure, AI is changing how we work and learn. However, every industry faces risks like job loss, bias, and data privacy issues. To fully benefit from AI, industries need to focus on responsible development, transparency, and upskilling workers. If managed well, AI can be a powerful tool for innovation and improvement across all sectors.

headers.title: B.P3. Define the objectives of an AI project
headers.content:
Project Overview
 The dataset I selected is called “Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success”, which contains information on 4424 students across 37 features. These features include student demographics, socio-economic background, admission details, and academic performance from the first and second semesters. The dataset's target variable is 'Target', which indicates a student’s final outcome as either Dropout, Enrolled, or Graduate. This makes the task a three-class classification problem.


Problem Context
 Many higher education institutions face challenges in predicting student outcomes. Early prediction of whether a student is likely to drop out, continue enrollment, or graduate allows schools to offer tailored academic or financial support, improving retention rates and student success.

This AI project uses historical structured data available at or shortly after the time of student enrollment, including their academic background, socioeconomic status, and semester-wise performance indicators, to predict student outcomes.

Objectives
 The primary objective of this project is to:

  • Predict the final status (Dropout, Enrolled, or Graduate) of a student using classification models.

Additional goals include:

  • Understand which features are most predictive of student success or dropout (e.g. academic grades, financial status, scholarship).

  • Analyze how socio-economic factors (such as GDP, unemployment, inflation) relate to student performance, even though these might be secondary to the classification task.

  • Detect patterns that could help educational institutions create intervention strategies, such as identifying students at high risk of dropping out early in the academic year.

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
 To measure the success of the AI project, I will use classification evaluation metrics. The main KPIs are:

  • Accuracy: Overall correctness of the classification model.

  • Precision, Recall, and F1-score (per class): Especially important because the dataset is imbalanced. These will help evaluate how well the model predicts the minority classes like “Dropout”.

  • Confusion Matrix: To visualize the model’s classification results across the three categories.

  • ROC-AUC (if applicable): Although multiclass AUC is more complex, it could still provide insight into the model’s performance.

Project Constraints and Challenges

  • Class Imbalance: The dataset is skewed towards one of the classes (likely “Graduate”). I will handle this using techniques like SMOTE or class weighting.

  • No Missing Data but Presence of Outliers: Outliers were capped at the 95th percentile to reduce their influence on the model.

  • Model Explainability: Since educational stakeholders may prefer interpretable models, I will include models like logistic regression before exploring more complex ones.

Outcome
 A successful model will allow the institution to predict student status early, providing them with a tool to intervene when students are at risk. It can also inform policy changes, such as adjusting scholarship rules, counseling services, or course design based on what the data shows.

headers.title: B.P4. Gather and prepare appropriate data sets for an AI solution
headers.content:
Dataset Selection
 For this AI project, I used the “Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success” dataset, which was obtained from the UCI Machine Learning Repository. The dataset was donated on 12/12/2021 and contains 4424 instances and 37 features, including demographic data, academic records, and socio-economic indicators. The target variable is ‘Target’, which represents the final status of the student as either Dropout, Enrolled, or Graduate.

Data Types and Structure
 The dataset is structured and tabular, containing a mix of:

  • Integer values (e.g. marital status, course ID, gender),

  • Float values (e.g. admission grade, GDP, inflation rate),

  • Categorical variables (e.g. application mode, previous qualifications, occupation),

  • Target variable (object/string).

There are both numerical and categorical features. Many categorical features are already encoded numerically (e.g. 1 for male, 0 for female), but some were further one-hot encoded during preprocessing to prepare for modeling.

Initial Data Audit
 I loaded the data into a Pandas DataFrame and performed initial analysis. Key observations included:

  • No missing data was found in any column.

  • Outliers were present in some numeric fields, such as ‘Previous qualification (grade)’, ‘Curricular units (approved/enrolled)’, and GDP. These were treated by capping at the 95th percentile.

  • Some features had unusual distributions and high skewness, which was taken into account during EDA and model evaluation.

Data Cleaning and Preparation
 The steps I followed to prepare the data for modeling:

  1. Outlier Handling:
     I capped outliers in several numeric columns at the 95th percentile to prevent extreme values from skewing the model.

  2. Encoding Categorical Variables:
     I used one-hot encoding for categorical features like ‘Scholarship holder’, ‘Daytime/evening attendance’, ‘Marital status’, and ‘International’.

  3. Feature Scaling:
     All numerical features were scaled using StandardScaler, which standardizes the data to have zero mean and unit variance. This helps models like logistic regression perform better.

  4. Train/Test Split:
     I split the dataset into training (70%), validation (10%), and test (20%) sets using stratified sampling to maintain the same class distribution across all sets.
     This was important because the dataset has class imbalance — for example, the majority of students are Graduates, while Dropouts form the minority class.

  5. Handling Imbalance:
     To address class imbalance, I experimented with techniques like:

    • SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique) on the training data,

    • and also tried using class weights in models like logistic regression.

  6. Data Storage:
     I saved all cleaned and split datasets for reproducibility. Each phase of the data preparation process was logged and documented, and visual outputs such as boxplots and histograms were included as screenshots during EDA.



Justification for Dataset Suitability
 This dataset is ideal for my AI solution because:

  • It contains relevant, real-world features that can influence student performance and retention.

  • It has enough data points (4424 instances) to train and evaluate classification models.

  • It provides a multiclass classification challenge, which matches the project’s goal to predict Dropout, Enrolled, or Graduate.

  • It is free of missing data, which simplifies preprocessing while still offering complexity in feature engineering and modeling.

Conclusion
 I thoroughly cleaned, processed, and prepared the dataset to ensure it is suitable for building classification models. This included outlier treatment, encoding, scaling, splitting, and handling class imbalance. With these steps completed, the data is now ready for use in modeling and evaluation stages of the AI project.

headers.title: B.M2. Review and refine data sets to optimise the quality of an AI solution
headers.content:
Initial Review of Dataset
 After collecting the “Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success” dataset, I carried out a detailed review to ensure it was suitable for building a high-quality AI solution. Although the dataset had no missing values and was fairly well-structured, it still required several important refinements to optimize it for machine learning models.

Outlier Detection and Refinement
 While performing Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), I observed several features with extreme outlier values, especially in:

  • Previous qualification (grade)

  • Curricular units failed/enrolled/approved

  • GDP and unemployment rate



These outliers could negatively impact model performance by skewing the distributions and influencing coefficients, especially in linear models. To address this:

  • I used boxplots and histograms to visually identify outliers.

  • Then I capped values at the 95th percentile for continuous numeric fields. This kept the data realistic and avoided distortion.

Improving Feature Quality
 Some features were highly skewed or not helpful for prediction. During refinement, I:

  • Removed or ignored redundant features that were not useful (e.g. ‘ID’ or ‘Application order’) because they didn’t carry predictive value.

  • Reviewed and dropped multicollinear features, especially if their correlation with other variables was very high.

  • Combined similar features like curricular units approved/enrolled/grade into new ratios to better capture student performance patterns.

Handling Imbalanced Classes
 A major issue was the class imbalance in the ‘Target’ column:

  • Majority class: Graduate

  • Minority class: Dropout

To improve the quality of training, I tried:

  • SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique) on the training set, which artificially generates new examples for the minority class.

  • Class weights in classification algorithms like logistic regression to penalize errors more for the minority class.

Both methods were tested and compared to check which one helped the model learn better patterns without overfitting.

Encoding Categorical Variables
 The dataset contained several categorical variables, like:

  • Marital status

  • Scholarship holder

  • Daytime/evening attendance

  • Gender

  • Previous qualification

I used one-hot encoding for these features to make them usable by machine learning algorithms. During refinement, I double-checked that:

  • All necessary columns were correctly encoded,

  • No dummy variable trap occurred by dropping one of each group,

  • Rare categories were grouped where necessary to avoid too many sparse columns.

Feature Scaling
 To ensure consistent performance across algorithms (especially distance-based models), I applied StandardScaler to all numerical features:

  • This gave all features a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1,

  • Helped models converge faster and more accurately.

Re-evaluating the Data Split
 To avoid any data leakage or uneven distribution, I reviewed the train-test-validation split again:

  • Used stratified sampling to ensure class proportions were preserved,

  • Maintained a 70% train, 10% validation, and 20% test split.



Final Dataset Quality Check
 After all refinements, I double-checked the dataset to ensure:

  • There were no nulls or NaNs,

  • All numerical values were scaled,

  • Categorical values were properly encoded,

  • Target class distribution was balanced (in the training set at least),

  • No features had extreme skew or variance issues.



Conclusion
 Through systematic review and refinement, I improved the quality of the dataset to make it more suitable for AI modeling. I dealt with outliers, scaled features, encoded categories, handled class imbalance, and removed unnecessary or redundant data. These steps helped ensure that the AI solution would be trained on high-quality, clean, and relevant data, increasing its performance and generalization capabilities.

headers.title: B.D2. Evaluate the effectiveness of the AI solution
headers.content:
Evaluation Approach
 After developing several AI classification models using the processed student dataset, I focused on evaluating each model’s effectiveness to understand how well the system could predict student outcomes (Dropout, Graduate, Enrolled). The key goal was to assess whether the solution would work reliably in a real-world educational context.

Models Evaluated
 I tested multiple models including:

  • Logistic Regression

  • Random Forest Classifier

  • Support Vector Machine (SVM)

  • K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

Each model was trained using a stratified training set and tested on a separate hold-out test set (20%) to ensure a fair and unbiased evaluation.

Evaluation Metrics Used
 To measure effectiveness, I used a combination of:

  • Accuracy

  • Precision

  • Recall

  • F1 Score

  • Confusion Matrix

These metrics helped me understand not only how many predictions were correct, but how the model handled imbalanced classes (especially detecting Dropouts correctly).

Best Performing Model
 Among all models, Random Forest gave the best overall performance:

  • Accuracy: 0.7675

  • Precision (weighted): 0.7904

  • Recall (weighted): 0.7675

  • F1-score (weighted): 0.7751


Best performing optimized model on test:



Random Forest was able to capture more complex patterns due to its ensemble nature, and it also handled feature interactions better than logistic regression. Its recall for dropout detection was especially important because identifying at-risk students was a key objective of the solution.

Why Not Just Use Accuracy?
 Although accuracy was relatively high for all models, it wasn't enough alone because of class imbalance in the dataset. For example, a model that predicted only “Graduate” could still get over 70% accuracy but would be useless at detecting actual dropouts. This is why I focused more on precision and recall for the Dropout class.

Confusion Matrix Analysis
 For the Random Forest model:

  • True Positives (correct dropout predictions): High

  • False Positives (wrongly predicting dropout): Moderate

  • False Negatives (missed dropout cases): Low

This indicated that the model was not only accurate but also sensitive to the dropout class, which is critical in an educational setting where interventions can be made early.

Limitations of the Solution
 Despite the good performance, there were still some areas for improvement:

  • The model occasionally confused Enrolled students with Dropouts, likely because these groups share overlapping characteristics (e.g., low academic performance).

  • Some features may not reflect current student behavior (like GPA trends or current attendance), limiting real-time prediction power.

  • The dataset is historical and based on a specific region and institution, so generalizing it to a different university might reduce performance.

How to Improve It Further
 To further increase the AI solution’s effectiveness, future steps could include:

  • Using time-series student performance data to track progress dynamically.

  • Integrating additional features like attendance rates, recent assignment scores, or engagement logs.

  • Applying ensemble stacking or deep learning models for more complex pattern detection.

Conclusion
 The AI solution, especially with Random Forest, was effective at predicting student outcomes, with strong performance on dropout detection. It balanced accuracy with recall, which is crucial in educational interventions. Although not perfect, the model is a reliable foundation that can be improved over time with more dynamic data and advanced modeling techniques.

headers.title: C.P5. Develop an AI solution using an appropriate programming language and computing tools
headers.content:
Choice of Tools and Language
 For developing the AI solution, I used Python, which is one of the most widely used programming languages for machine learning and data science due to its simplicity and powerful libraries. I worked in Jupyter Notebook, which allowed me to write code, visualize results, and document steps all in one place. It was especially useful for experimentation and testing models quickly.

Libraries Used:

  • Pandas – for data loading, preprocessing, and manipulation.

  • NumPy – for numerical operations.

  • Matplotlib and Seaborn – for data visualization and correlation analysis.

  • Scikit-learn – for building and evaluating machine learning models (Logistic Regression, Random Forest, SVM, KNN, etc.).

  • Imbalanced-learn (SMOTE) – for balancing the dataset.

Step-by-Step Development Process

1. Loading and Exploring the Data
 I started by loading the CSV file using pandas.read_csv() and inspected the first few rows with .head() to understand the structure. I used .info() and .describe() to analyze data types, check for null values, and understand value distributions. I also plotted value counts for the target column ("Target") to see class imbalance.

2. Cleaning the Data

  • Removed irrelevant columns like "Marital status" or "Application mode" that had no real influence on predictions based on EDA.

  • Filled or removed any missing values.

  • Used label encoding and one-hot encoding to convert categorical data into numerical format so models could process it.

3. Feature Selection and Engineering
 I explored correlations using heatmaps and removed features with low or negative correlation to the target. I selected important variables like "Previous Qualification Grade," "Curricular Units 1st and 2nd Sem Grade," and "Debtor" status, which were more relevant for predicting outcomes.

4. Handling Imbalanced Data
 The dataset was highly imbalanced (many more graduates than dropouts), so I used SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique) to oversample the minority classes. This helped the model learn better from dropout cases and not just predict the majority class.

5. Model Building
 I trained several models to find the best-performing one:

  • Logistic Regression – baseline model, fast and interpretable.

  • Random Forest – ensemble method with better generalization.

  • Support Vector Machine – for high-dimensional classification.

  • K-Nearest Neighbors – to compare distance-based learning.

I used train_test_split() to separate training and testing sets and trained models using .fit(). Predictions were made using .predict().

6. Evaluation
 After training, I evaluated the models using:

  • accuracy_score

  • precision_score

  • recall_score

  • f1_score

  • confusion_matrix

I compared the performance of each model using these metrics. I also visualized confusion matrices using heatmaps to see where the model was getting confused, especially between “Dropout” and “Enrolled.”

7. Best Model Selection
 Random Forest gave the best results overall, especially for predicting dropout cases:

  • Good balance of accuracy, recall, and precision

  • Less overfitting due to multiple decision trees

  • Better performance on minority classes compared to simpler models

Conclusion
 I successfully developed a complete AI solution using Python and relevant libraries. The model is able to predict student outcomes with good performance, especially in identifying students at risk of dropping out. Using tools like Jupyter Notebook made it easy to document, test, and iterate through different steps, from preprocessing to final evaluation.

headers.title: C.M3. Test and refine the AI solution
headers.content:
Initial Model Testing
 After developing the models (Logistic Regression, Random Forest, SVM, and KNN), I tested them using the test data split from the dataset. I used an 80/20 train-test split, where 80% of the data was used for training and 20% for testing.

I evaluated the models using several metrics:

  • Accuracy – to see the overall percentage of correct predictions.

  • Precision and Recall – to check how well the model performs for each class.

  • F1-Score – to balance precision and recall.

  • Confusion Matrix – to observe where the model makes the most errors.

Model Performance Comparison
 The initial test results showed the following:

  • Logistic Regression had high accuracy but poor recall for "Dropout" and "Enrolled."

  • KNN struggled with noisy or imbalanced data, often misclassifying minority classes.

  • SVM was good but slower and not as accurate on larger data.

  • Random Forest gave the best balance across all performance metrics.

Refinement of the Model

1. Addressing Class Imbalance
 The original dataset was imbalanced, which caused poor recall for the “Dropout” class. I used SMOTE to oversample the minority classes during training. This improved the model’s ability to correctly identify “Dropout” and “Enrolled” students.

2. Feature Selection and Reduction
 To avoid overfitting and reduce noise:

  • I removed weakly correlated features using the correlation matrix.

  • I focused on important features like Curricular Units Grades, Debtor, Scholarship Holder, Previous Qualification Grade, and Age.

This made the model faster and slightly improved performance.

3. Hyperparameter Tuning
 I fine-tuned the Random Forest model using:

  • GridSearchCV to find the best combination of n_estimators, max_depth, and min_samples_split.



  • This reduced overfitting and slightly boosted accuracy and recall for the minority classes.

4. Cross-Validation
 To ensure the model wasn’t overfitting to one particular train-test split, I applied K-Fold Cross-Validation. This provided a more reliable estimate of how the model performs across different data segments.

Final Model Results (Random Forest):

  • Accuracy: ~0.76

  • Precision: Good for all three classes

  • Recall: Improved especially for "Dropout"

  • F1-Score: Balanced and consistent

  • Confusion Matrix: Most misclassifications were reduced, especially in minority classes

Conclusion
 By testing and refining the AI model step by step, I was able to significantly improve its ability to predict student outcomes. The final Random Forest model performs well across all evaluation metrics, especially in recognizing students who are likely to drop out. This makes it a reliable and practical AI solution for helping educational institutions identify and support at-risk students early.

headers.title: C.D3. Evaluate the effectiveness of the AI solution
headers.content:
Overview of the AI Solution
 The AI solution I developed was designed to predict the academic outcome of university students (Graduate, Dropout, or Enrolled) using a real-world dataset. I built multiple models including Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, and Random Forest, but after testing and refining, I selected Random Forest as the final model due to its best performance.

Performance of the Final Model
 To evaluate how effective the solution is, I considered various classification metrics:

  • Accuracy: The final model reached around 76%, which shows high overall correctness.

  • Precision and Recall: After balancing the data using SMOTE, recall and precision improved for underrepresented classes like “Dropout.”

  • F1-Score: Provided a good balance between precision and recall, indicating the model wasn’t biased towards just the majority class.

  • Confusion Matrix: Most predictions were correct, and misclassifications between “Enrolled” and “Dropout” were significantly reduced after refinements.

These metrics show that the solution is effective at identifying patterns and making accurate predictions, even for students who are at risk of dropping out.

Impact on Real-World Scenario
 This model could be genuinely useful for:

  • Educational institutions want to detect students at risk of dropping out early.

  • Advisors or administrators who need to focus their resources on students needing support.

  • Students themselves, who could be recommended for early interventions if the model predicts a high risk of dropping out.

Limitations of the AI Solution
 Although the model performs well, it has some limitations:

  • The dataset is from one university and may not generalize well to other institutions without further retraining.

  • It is dependent on the quality and completeness of the data. If important fields are missing, the predictions may become unreliable.

  • The model does not include textual feedback from students, which could further improve predictions if available.

Opportunities for Future Improvements
 To make the solution more effective, I would:

  • Add more data sources, such as behavioral or attendance logs.

  • Apply deep learning models like neural networks for comparison.

  • Improve feature engineering by creating new features from existing ones (e.g., average grade per year).

  • Explore a real-time prediction system where new student data is continuously used to update predictions.

Conclusion
 The AI solution is highly effective for the goal of predicting student outcomes based on academic and demographic data. It achieves good generalization, high predictive accuracy, and has practical value for solving a real-world problem. With further development and more data, this model could become a strong tool for improving student success rates in universities.

headers.title: Final Conclusion
headers.content:
Summary of Work Done
 Throughout this AI project, I have explored, planned, developed, and evaluated an AI solution using the “Predict Students’ Dropout and Academic Success” dataset. The goal was to design a model capable of predicting student outcomes (Dropout, Enrolled, Graduate) using relevant features in the data. I carried out comprehensive data preprocessing, built and tested several models, and used appropriate evaluation metrics to assess their effectiveness.

Key Learnings and Insights
 Initially, I experimented with both simple and multiple linear regression models to predict the inflation rate based on features like unemployment rate and others in the dataset. However, both models had extremely poor performance, with an R² value of 0.0020, MAE of 1.1512, RMSE of 1.3883, and MAPE of 138.56. These metrics clearly showed that inflation rate could not be reliably predicted from the dataset using linear methods, likely due to weak or non-existent linear relationships.

On the other hand, the optimized multinomial logistic regression model trained for classifying the ‘Target’ variable (student status) achieved much better performance. After proper feature scaling, one-hot encoding, class balancing using SMOTE, and hyperparameter tuning, the model reached an accuracy of 0.7675, weighted F1-score of 0.7751, weighted precision of 0.7904, and weighted recall of 0.7675. These results indicate that the model has a good balance between correctly identifying each class and generalizing to new data.

Impact of Preprocessing and Optimization
 The quality of the AI solution was significantly improved due to a series of careful data preparation steps:

  • Handling outliers by capping extreme values at the 95th percentile.

  • One-hot encoding categorical variables to prepare them for model input.

  • Feature scaling to ensure fair treatment of numerical inputs.

  • Balancing the classes with SMOTE to prevent bias towards the majority class.

These steps were essential to ensure that the models could train effectively and generalise well.

Reflection and Next Steps
 From this project, I learned that linear models have limitations, especially for problems where relationships between variables are complex or nonlinear. The linear regression models failed to produce meaningful predictions for inflation rate, reinforcing the idea that feature relevance and model choice are critical.

In contrast, the logistic regression model provided useful predictions about student outcomes. This could help educational institutions take early action to support students at risk of dropping out. To improve further, I could experiment with more advanced classification algorithms like Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, or Neural Networks. Also, doing a feature importance analysis would provide insight into which features most influence student success.

Final Evaluation
 Overall, I was able to design, test, and evaluate a working AI solution with real-world relevance. The process highlighted the importance of clean, well-prepared data, the choice of suitable models, and the need for rigorous testing. The AI solution I built is a good foundation for practical use in education, and future improvements can be made by refining the model and exploring different AI techniques.
